results.title: Headliner: NoviNews
results.brief_description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society.

constellations_primary.name: Fake news: too little too late
constellations_primary.description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society, something that is fast becoming one of the biggest concerns of our age.

results.description:
Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society. Players take the role of a ‘headliner’, which is like a chief editor at a news outlet. The player must decide what stories and angles to publish, and their choices have wide-reaching effects in the game world. Reject stories about creating national healthcare services? People get sick in the street. Approve stories on the benefits of synthetic recreational drugs? Addiction runs rampant.

These stories aren’t presented as obviously ‘right’ or ‘wrong’ choices: the game lets the player’s own ethics and morals guide their decisions – which can create a peaceful society or burn it to the ground.
description_for_label:

These stories aren’t presented as obviously ‘right’ or ‘wrong’ choices: the game lets the player’s own ethics and morals guide their decisions – which can create a peaceful society or burn it to the ground.

results.title: Forge and ornamental iron
results.creator_credit: Alan Lloyd, Joe Hayward and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hand Operations-Metal Work”.
A description of the gas forge and its operation. Shows various tongs, parts of the anvil, and safety rules in forge operation.

results.title: Hacknet
results.creator_credit: Fellow Traveller and Team Fractal Alligator
results.brief_description: Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.

constellations_primary.name: Hack the planet
constellations_primary.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

results.description:
If you’ve ever wanted to know what hacking is really like, Hacknet is the game for you. Simulating a true-to-life terminal environment, the game tasks the player with using computer commands similar to what a real hacker would use. These skills are put to use solving the murder of a character named Bit, who contacts the player through a computer program initiated after their death.

Developed by Adelaide-based Matt Trobbiani, Hacknet aims to create a mix between over-the-top movie-style hacking and a realistic experience: the game is played through command lines and multiple computer windows.
description_for_label:

results.title: Instrumental program
results.creator_credit: F Whitman Trecartin, Rex Tasker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Halifax Music”.
Displays some of the talents developed by students within the Halifax School Music Department system. From choral groups to jazz bands these youngsters have fun with their music and in so doing seem to involve their audiences in that enjoyment.

results.title: General music program
results.creator_credit: F Whitman Trecartin, Rex Tasker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Halifax Music”.
Halifax Music is a documentary on the teaching methods of the Music Department of the Halifax School Board. Many of the basic concepts originated with the Hungarian composer Kodaly. Musical education is continuous from the primary grades through to Grade XII. The film tours the various classrooms, demonstrating methods and results, and shows how learning and enjoyment go hand in hand.

results.title: The Indian Pacific
results.creator_credit: Ron Bollman, Cathy Beitz and Banksia Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
Traverse the full distance between the Indian and Pacific Oceans, from Sydney to Perth, in a 2,700 mile odyssey. One of the world’s great long distance trains, the Indian Pacific, rolls across Australia like a miniature city on wheels, illuminating the colorful and quirky history, cultures and countryside of Australia as it goes. The heart of the Outback emerges in the Nullarbor Plain, offering a glimpse into the oldest continuing culture on earth. We stop several times along the way and meet the people who have made the remote outback their home. The three day journey on Australia’s crown jewel of rail lines promises all that the country itself has to offer - vivid landscapes, exotic creatures, mystical destinations, and unforgettable characters. Presented in two parts: Sydney to Adelaide and Adelaide to Perth.

group_siblings.title: The Queenslander: tales of the tropical north

results.title: The Ghan: a spiritual connection
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Great train journeys of Australia”.
The legendary Ghan was named after the Afghans who with their camels opened the supply line through Australia’s interior. On this rich and fascinating journey from Adelaide to the Red Centre of Australia, traverse some of the world’s most ancient and inhospitable terrain, exploring the history of this great train line. At the remote town of Pimba, attend a rock concert in the middle of the Australian desert, arranged by the world music organisation WOMAD. Later, when the Ghan pulls into Alice Springs, visit Uluru, the largest free standing rock in the world. Uluru is a sacred aboriginal dreaming site that was returned to it’s original owners in 1985 and is now one of Australia’s most celebrated tourist attractions.
